title: Question 21

children: A 62-year-old man is evaluated because of a slowly changing mole above his ear. He recalls several blistering sunburns as a child and adolescent.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The lesion is
shown
. A complete skin examination reveals several seborrheic keratoses; some are irritated and inflamed. The patient also has a pigmented actinic keratosis on his forehead.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

In general, the ABCDEs of identifying characteristics can help diagnose melanoma, where “A” stands for Asymmetry, “B” for irregular Border, “C” for multiple Colors, “D” for Diameter greater than 6 mm, and “E” for Evolution or change over time.

All suspicious pigmented lesions must be biopsied; the preferred method to biopsy a pigmented lesion is an excisional biopsy with a 1- to 2-mm margin to obtain the entire lesion and to prevent sampling error.
This patient most likely has nodular malignant melanoma (
Option B

). In general, the ABCDEs of identifying characteristics can help diagnose melanoma, where “A” stands for Asymmetry, “B” for irregular Border, “C” for multiple Colors, “D” for Diameter greater than 6 mm, and “E” for Evolution or change over time. There are four clinical subtypes of melanoma: superficial spreading, lentigo maligna, acral lentiginous, and nodular melanoma. Risk factors include ultraviolet light (both chronic and intermittent blistering sunburns), genetics (family history, and
CDKN2A
and
CDK4

gene mutations), large number of nevi, dysplastic nevi, and fair skin. Nodular melanomas typically present as uniformly dark blue or black "berry-like" lesions that most commonly originate from normal skin but may also arise as amelanotic lesions with a pink hue, making diagnosis difficult. This patient has a small back nodule and a large, mainly pink nodule with some melanotic pigmentation, making the diagnosis easier. Nodular melanomas can also arise from preexisting nevi. All suspicious pigmented lesions must be biopsied. The preferred method to biopsy a pigmented lesion is an excisional biopsy with a 1- to 2-mm margin to obtain the entire lesion and to prevent sampling error. Poor prognostic factors include male gender, increasing age, increased tumor thickness (Breslow depth), ulceration, increased tumor mitotic rate, and head/neck/trunk locations.
Lentigo maligna (
Option A

) is a slow-growing in-situ melanoma most commonly seen on the head and neck of older, fair-skinned persons as a pigmented patch; it is caused by substantial cumulative sun exposure. It has a prolonged radial growth phase and can be present for many years before developing invasive, malignant vertical growth. After invasion, lentigo maligna is called lentigo maligna melanoma and is distinguishable from benign processes by positive ABCDE criteria.
Actinic keratoses (AKs) (
Option C

) are squamous cell precursor lesions occurring in sun-damaged areas. Pigmentation is occasionally present, but pigmented AKs behave in a manner identical to typical AKs, with rough and scaly surface features. They are usually small, measuring only 1 to 3 mm. In this patient with a large and enlarging smooth lesion, lentigo maligna melanoma is more likely.
Seborrheic keratoses (
Option D

) are brown, scaly, waxy papules and plaques that appear “stuck on” and occur in older persons. Although benign, they may be difficult to differentiate definitively from melanoma; atypical lesions are often biopsied. This patient's smooth nodular, darkly pigmented lesion arising from a preexisting nevus makes seborrheic keratosis unlikely.

references: Rashid S, Tsao H. Recognition, staging, and management of melanoma. Med Clin North Am. 2021;105:643-661.
